"Unfortunately for everyone, due to shortage of time, you will only have a day to prepare for these tests."
’That’s new.’
The last time, they had given quite a while to prepare.
Maybe it was because of the new recruits that arrived after those deaths.
’They probably wanted them to adjust properly.’
Mikhail could see the expressions of discomfort and despair on people’s faces at Avalon’s words.
He didn’t have any problem with the time. Nor did his squadron.
Their abilities–not just mana but also physical– were enough for them to always place high enough in the list.
Especially Mikhail.
Outside of just his squadron duties, he made sure to keep himself in shape physically.
As for his mana abilities, Mikhail was known to have the largest–if not, one of the largest– mana pools among the men.
It was the difference between his squadron and the majority of other ones.
Despite their strength, they made sure to keep improving.
"That’s all. If you want, you can use the available grounds for training."
Avalon pointed out.
"The list for the exercises and schedule will be sent to the squadron leaders in a few hours."
Ending his speech, Avalon left the ground, leaving everyone alone.
Mikhail turned back, addressing his squadron now.
"Nothing new. Same as last time, maybe even easier because of the reduced exercises. However, as always, don’t take it easy," Mikhail said.
Everyone nodded.
"I’m looking forward to the elemental tests," Oscar excitedly said.
"Of course you would, it’s a breeze for you." Icarus sighed.
It was true.
Oscarl’s rank for Cindralis Essentia was higher than anyone else among the men.
Mikhail’s flames were nothing compared to him.
"I’m looking forward to the races." Yvan chose to put his thoughts forward as well.
"Again, it’s because of your Essentia." Icarus pulled his arms behind his back.
Yvan chose to strike back at him.
"You are just salty you can’t win against Oscar in elemental tests."
The attack seemed to work as Mikhail saw Icarus shudder before quickly waving it off.
"Whatever, I’m better in physical tests anyway."
Mikhail turned to Modric.
"What about you?"
At his question, Modric simply shrugged.
"Never had any interests to top in these aspects."
’It’s true.’
Mikhail remembered.
Despite having the highest rank for Borealis and Thundralis, Modric had never been the competitive type.
"Though.."
"Hmm?"
"If there’s one thing I’m looking forward to it’s one-on-one spars," Modric said, the corners of his lips almost pulling up.
"Yeah, same." Oscar exclaimed.
"Me as well." Yvan raised his hand.
"Me too," Icarus smiled at Mikhail.
Mikhail knew what they meant.
They weren’t looking forward exactly to the one-on-one spars.
They were looking forward to fighting him.
And he had no problem with that.
"Sure." Mikhail accepted their challenge, knowing what they meant.
"What about you though?" Icarus asked.
At his question, everyone’s heads turned toward Mikhail as well, filled with curiosity.
All of them knew about what kind of person Mikhail was.
Despite being one of the strongest men at the camp, he didn’t like to display much of it.
He was one of the only few men in the camp with 3 Essentia and the only one if he chose to reveal Otharis.
He had not one but two elements at the second highest rank possible.
But this wasn’t all.
Mikhail had the record for highest scores in physical and mental examination for a year.
So there was pretty much nothing that he couldn’t get a good score in.
Yet, even with all this, he didn’t show much of it willingly.
It was not to say that he didn’t try or he was hiding it from the public.
No.
That was not the case.
It was just that Mikhail never saw a point in such competitions.
What mattered to him was at the end of the day, only his and his squadron’s survival.
Trophies and accolades were nothing if you couldn’t survive in a war or battle.
His whole squadron knew about this as well.
So even though they knew the answer, they wanted to see if he would try at least this time around.
’Hmmm..’
Mikhail didn’t know what to think about it.
Normally, he would have declined to do much but, this time around, it was different.
He had to change his ways.
It was the only way to change his future later on.
The plotline would certainly mess up a lot, but when did he ever care about that.
It had already started changing the moment he accepted the first quest.
The moment he changed the drill routes.
Surprisingly, at that moment, a notification came in front of him.
—————〔Chronicle II〕—————
[Condition:]
•
Place as the highest rank in 3 categories you have never participated in or never topped in.
•
Break the records of your previous categories.
[Rewards:]
•
Character Progression: +5%
•
Mana Increase: +80
———————————————
There it was.
The final nail in the coffin.

chapters.title: Chapter 26: Selections (Intro)
chapters.content:
Chapter 26: Selections (Intro)
[The Day After]
Mikhail had accepted the request given to him by the system.
Though he couldn’t understand the purpose of the quest.
In his mind, the quests given to him by the system related with his future in this life.
Not just the Character Progression, but the overall meaning of the quests as well.
In a sense, the previous quest did relate to his future.
It allowed him to change a significant point of his previous life, turning around the complete future.
So he couldn’t understand how this new quest would do that.
Or maybe it wasn’t meant to have any relation to his future and were just random quests at the current point in time.
Mikhail made that hypothesis just after one quest after all.
Last night, the list for all the aspects in the assignments test had been given to him.
___________________
•
Elemental Tests
•
Track Race
•
Physical Tests
•
Mental Examination
•
Survival Tactics
•
Alchemy Tests
•
Spellcasting Tests
•
One-on-One Spars
__________________
A total of 8 categories, unlike the usual 10.
Categories like Medical Tests etc weren’t able to be conducted right now.
Quite a portion of the infirmary had been damaged under the attack and the rest was still filled with heavily injured cadets.
In any case, in the given 8 categories, Mikhail always took Physical Tests and Mental Examination.
He had the top record in both of the tests.
And while he could try doing the same for other records as well, he never did it.
Unfortunately or fortunately, because of the quest this time, he had to not only pick 3 different categories other than his usual ones.
He had to also top them at the 1st position.
From the above list, Mikhail already picked the 3 categories he was going to participate in.
They were Elemental Tests, Spellcasting Tests and One-on-One Spars.
For the first, he could guarantee himself a top position as a Norvalis Magus.
For Cindralis, it would be hard to beat Oscar and his talent in Aqualis wasn’t that high enough.
The second was obvious. His Dragma was the perfect tool for this aspect.
Not to mention his oath abilities that further allowed him to reduce his casting time.
As for the last category, it was obvious as well.
Just like his squadron, Mikhail himself was eager to fight them as well.
Only by assessing their abilities in battle himself would he be able to provide them further advice.
However, at the same time, he feared that this was the riskiest category he had taken.
Because of course, his squadron wasn’t going to be the only team he would fight.
And in fighting different people–even though he was confident he would win–there was definitely a chance for him to lose.
Which meant the failure of the quest.
All in all, he could just try his best.
Today was the first day of the assignment tests which would further span over a course of a week.
As he headed outside his tent, Mikhail was quick to see his squadron, waiting for him.
"Morning." He greeted, making their faces turn.
"Morning!" Oscar waved, gesturing to him to come quickly.
Joining them, the team started to move towards the grounds.
Unfortunately, they were due to separate soon because of their different categories.
There were 8 categories and the time was short. So the ideal way was to carry out multiple of them at the same time.
And with that, each category would have a different venue as well.
"It’s Physical Tests for me first." Icarus told the team, his arms wrapped behind his head.
"Elemental Tests for me." Oscarl declared in response as well.
"Survival Tactics for me." Yvan smiled.
All of them turned toward Modric, the second last person left.
"It’s Spellcasting for me," he said, showing no excitement unlike Icarus or Oscar.
Basically, all categories were open at all times. You could go and attempt at any time you wanted.
Except some certain ones.
At the end of the day, your record would just be shortlisted among the men.
As he had said before, it wasn’t an exam or anything. It was a simple fitness test conducted to see who was in shape.
As they were about to separate, Mikhail heard Yvan ask from him.
"What about you Mikhail? What are you going to attempt first?" He put his palm to his chin in curiosity.
Mikhail, not surprised by his question, barely showed a reaction on his face and answered after a moment of thought.
"I think I’ll take the Mental Examination first."
The first one to respond was Modric with a nod.
"That’s a good idea. The fresher you are in that category, the higher score you can obtain," he explained.
Mikhail returned the nod, affirming his words to the confused team.
Modric was used to taking the Mental Examination as well, so knew about it.
"Since the Mental Examination tests your willpower, your resilience and your pain resistance, it is advised to go and attempt it with a fresh mind."
Mikhail summed it up for the team, providing them the basic idea of the test.
Just as he expected, the team understood the rest of what he meant by those words.
"Ah," Yvan nodded to his words.
"In any case, let’s split up here. The faster we get done, the faster we can meet up later on." Mikhail advised.
Modric nodded, supporting his decision and the team followed a second later.
"Okay. Good luck to everyone! Let’s meet up here later with good news." Icarus smiled,
The team–except Mikhail, as always—smiled lightly at his words.
Icarus put his hand forward in a fist bump, gesturing everyone to join him
"On the count of 3, everyone join your hands as always."
In the team, it was common for Icarus to do this before any event.
According to him, it boosted his and the team’s morale for the event.
Seeing no problem as always, the team joined their hands together, even Mikhail.
"Alright, everyone! Once again, good luck for your assignment exams!" Icarus retraced his hand along with everyone, pushing it in the air.
"Yeah." Mikhail smiled lightly.
It was good to be back with them.

chapters.title: Chapter 27: Mental Exam
chapters.content:
Chapter 27: Mental Exam
Mikhail entered the Mental Examination building, now alone and separated from his squad.
It wasn’t his first time coming here so he already knew the way.
The building wasn’t too small but neither was it too large.
It was moderate in size with its entire structure being decorated in white tiles.
The building’s furniture had different lab equipment and machines placed inside, giving one the feeling of a research lab.
It was all basic equipment however, nothing that advanced.
Well, in a certain sense, it already was.
Mikhail saw different higher-ups quickly walking through the building, trying to get the equipment ready.
Along with their normal black coats, they wore white lab coats that highlighted their position.
Mikhail could already see some of the men present in the facility, waiting for their turn.
They weren’t all that much however.
A major reason for this was the toll that mental examination put on a person.
Even though he had said that it was recommended to come here because of a fresh mind, it had the opposite effect as well.
The tests taken during the examination could induce stress and exhaustion in the person, even making him feel dizzy.
It was why most people who wanted to attempt multiple categories in a day avoided taking this test.
Of course, it wasn’t the same for himself. He was just built differently.
"Oh you’re here. Same as last time?"
Mikhail heard a feminine voice from behind him, turning after recognizing him.
There she was.
A woman that seemed to be in her late 20’s with short black hair styled in a bob-cut with blue eyes just like him.
Emily Tate.
Mikhail knew her well.
She was the lead researcher here in the mental examination lab, overseeing all the tests and results.
Also one of the only few women ever allowed on the wall. For what purpose she got sent here, he didn’t know.
He had gotten well acquainted with her over time when coming for his tests.
"Yes."
Mikhail nodded.
"Hmm..." Emily put the pencil to her chin, leaning closer and examining him from all sides.
Feeling weird because of her closeness, he was quick to ask.
"What’s wrong?"
"Nothing much, I’m just checking if you have any injuries from that incident. It would be a problem if our star prospect had any problems."
She searched his face to see any reaction about being mentioned as a ’star prospect’.
Unfortunately for her, she found nothing but a straight face.
Mikhail saw her face twitch as if she got annoyed.
He quickly changed the topic.
"I’m fine. Just some light injuries but I recovered quickly."
Emily smugged, spinning the pencil in her hand as she turned to guide him.
"Of course you did. Why was I even getting worried about you?"
Mikhail stared at her back as she walked.
She wasn’t even worried for him personally.
She was worried about the state of their ’star prospect’ not ’Mikhail’ himself.
Despite their informal way of talking, they were nothing more than acquaintances.
He knew the woman only saw him as a means to her research because of his exceptional talent.
Normally, one would stay away from such a person after knowing this but not Mikhail.
Because it wasn’t like he wasn’t getting anything out of her.
In addition, he knew that the woman was aware that Mikhail knew about her plans.
It was a mutual relation where both were using each other.
Unfortunately for her, Mikhail barely gave her any chance to take unnecessary advantage of him.
As they walked through the lab, Mikhail saw various men seated on the benches at the side, waiting for their turn.
He could feel their stares of envy and jealousy digging a hole in his back.
These men barely ever got to see a woman up here after all. And now she was getting smuggy with him.
But they knew this would happen.
At this point, they were used to Mikhail always having the first turn in this examination.
It was the reason why they didn’t bother to make a queue already and remained seated on their benches.
Reaching a white door, Emily turned back to him.
"As always, head inside and get ready. I’ll report to the lab and we’ll start the examination right away."
Mikhail nodded.
"Alright."
"Tell me if you feel the slightest inconvenience or weirdness okay?" She asked, signs of fake worry in her eyes.
Mikhail ignored her question, opening the doors and heading inside.
From behind he could hear Emily chuckling.
"Straightforward as ever huh?"
Ignoring her once more, he focused forward.
Through the doors was a large square-shaped room completely decorated with black concrete all around.
There was absolutely nothing in the whole room.
Not even a source of light as Mikhail saw the dimly illuminated room because of the outside light.
However, there was one thing that could be noticed.
It was the medium-sized white circle boundary in the middle of the room.
Just from a glance, one could feel that it seemed to be a space separate from the rest of the space.
’And it is.’
Closing the doors to shroud the room in darkness again, Mikhail started walking to the circle.
As the room was covered in dark again, the boundary suddenly illuminated to provide an eerie luminescence.
From the walls, Mikhail heard Emily’s booming voice.
"You know the drill don’t you?"
Mikhail didn’t answer, only doing a simple nod to confirm.
"Good, settle down and we can start the tests. It should take no longer than 30 minutes."
Stepping inside the small circle, Mikhail instantly felt as if his body was entering a separate dimension.
He could feel his senses distort and a weird sensation pass through his body.
’Illusias Magic.’
Without wasting any moment, he sat down inside the small circle.
It wasn’t that large in size. Moving a lot would definitely place him out.
Readying himself, Mikhail spoke up.
"I’m ready."
To show that his confirmation was heard, the boundary light of the circle just turned from white to red.
The whole place gave off a haunting, eerie vibe now.
Mikhail gave no reaction, already used to the process as he closed his eyes.
"The test will commence in 3, 2, 1."
"Now."
The second it began, Mikhail felt his surroundings change, as if he was warping through something.
The test was simple.
Through the use of Illusias and Spiritalis Magic, the castle would induce various traumas and scenes for the participant inside the circle.
The experiences given would vary from past memories to even purely crafted imaginary scenes to see the participant’s reactions.
At a certain point, even various emotions like pain would be pushed into the participant to see his reaction to the situation.
At any point in time, if the participant passed out or chose to run and moved out of the circle, the test would be over.
With each passing second, the hardness and severity of the challenges would increase.
And the further user showcased his mental endurance, the higher his score would go.
The scores of the participants were given from 1 to a 100 and the average score of a normal participant was 46 to 55.
In talented cases, this score could even go up to 60 to 65 but no further than that.
Any further and the participant had to be a psycho or mental patient to endure that much.
Of course, adults could go way higher but we were talking about 19 to 20 year old young people here.
Even if they were killers or some of the most morally disgusting people here on the wall, everyone had fears.
But only one certain man had displayed a score that was never seen before in the history of mental examinations.
At just the age of 21, he had a mind-breaking score of 72.
And that man...
Was none other than Mikhail Hendrix.
___________

chapters.title: Chapter 28: One Who Withstands Despair
chapters.content:
Chapter 28: One Who Withstands Despair
The moment Mikhail felt the surroundings change, he also started hearing them.
Spirits.
Even with his eyes closed, the darkness in front of his eyes started to subside now.
It gave way to a bright light that illuminated his whole surroundings, which were now in the form of a bright desert.
’Hmm?’
He was now seated in the middle of a long and cracked railway track, one that parted through the sands into the far light.
The heat immediately assaulted his thick clothes and bandages and the bright sun made him squint his eyes.
Wherever he turned to see, there was nothing but sand all around.
However, not for long as he suddenly heard a booming sound from behind.
CHING!
The sound of a train, tearing through the air at unmeasurable speeds.
But despite the nearing danger, Mikhail felt no sort of nervousness.
Carefully, with one sharp motion, he turned his head back to see the train.
Only to find it an inch away from his face, about to send him flying when suddenly..
CHING! WHOOSH!
The moment it connected with him, the train disappeared into a wisp of smoke.
Mikhail felt nothing.
But then suddenly, he felt a booming noise of the train ramming into him from behind.
BOOM!
Mikhail felt pain coursing through his whole body and his brain screamed to dive forward.
Fortunately for him, he had been through this before.
It was all fake.
Bearing through the pain, Mikhail ignored the urge to dive and remained rooted in his place, despite the threatening voice from behind.
The pain continued for a good minute before suddenly disappearing, along with the scene.
As it did, Mikhail heaved a large sigh of relief.
’Bring it on.’
From the corner of the darkness, he heard a group of hysterical shrieking laughs.
"Oh ho, we have an interesting prospect. Hehe."
The next moment, the voice suddenly came right beside his ear and a painful sensation of nails dragging across his back was felt.
***
[In the Lab]
Emily gazed at the screen curiously, seeing Mikhail’s progress.
"23. 24."
She turned to a member beside her, who focused on another screen.
"What’s the heartbeat?"
"It’s still stable at 74 but we can see signs of rise."
Emily tapped the pen against her chin turning back to the monitor that displayed the inside of the room.
"Hmm, I see. Impressive as always. Most people would start breaking by now."
On the screen, she could see the dark room with Mikhail sitting in the center with his eyes closed.
The illuminated circle lit up Mikhail’s face, which was currently a peaceful calm.
There were no signs of distress or frowns on his face. But then again, it was just the start.
At least for him.
Emily turned to another member on the other side.
"Any changes in his body?"
The reply came instantly.
"Nothing yet. Stable as ever, he’s taking it very well."
Emily nodded, turning her gaze quickly back to the screen.
"Of course he is, he’s Mikhail."
***
[After a couple of minutes]
Light gasps escaped from Mikhail’s sweaty face now.
’Annoying spirits.’
His gaze went down to his bandaged arms, or at least what they formerly were.
Now, the bandages had been ripped and blood and flesh dripped all over his arms.
Stabs of pain coursed through his whole body from time to time, making his face scrunch.
Leg first.
"Tch!"
Then suddenly, his shoulder.
"Argh!" Mikhail gritted his teeth.
The shrieking laughter from time to time right by his ear and then away were making his control slip away.
Suddenly..
SCREECH!
A tearing scream echoed in his right ear, making his body convulse with instinct to close his ears.
Unfortunately, it slipped away from his control.
His chest pressed heavy against him as a tearing pain tore through his abdomen, like a spear had ripped through him.
"Argh!" He collapsed to the floor.
Struggling to breath with the increasing pain, Mikhail felt his consciousness slipping.
’What is this?’
He couldn’t understand.
How long had it been?
5 minutes? 6 Minutes?
How much of a score would be for this amount of despair?
39? 40.
’P-pathetic.’
This was way lower than his usual attempts, so why was he struggling?
Why was he struggling even after a life full of despair behind his back this time?
Why was he so unfamiliar with despair after all the loss he had sustained in his previous life?
After going through all those struggles and pain in the outer world, he was struggling with this?
What about the despair when he witnessed his squadron right in front of him?
When despite the oath to always protect them, he was helpless as he watched the beasts devour them?
Incomparable. Nothing could describe what Mikhail felt at that moment.
What about all those days that he spent in the harsh snow, watching himself wither to death?
When all he could see with his fading vision was the strewn bloody bodies of his death, slowly rotting away?
WHAT OF IT!?
’Pathetic.’
PATHETIC!
’Disgusting. Despicable. Trash. Pathetic. Bullshit.’
Was this all that he could amount to after all that pain and despair?
Was this all he could show for what he went through?
Was this it!?
’NO!’
No. This wasn’t his relation with despair.
They weren’t strangers. No. They were far from it.
If he was an orphan, then despair was his adopter.
If he was helpless, then despair was his helper.
If he was hungry, then despair was his feeder.
If he was crying, then despair was his relief.
If he was screaming, then despair was his soother.
In whatever situation he was in, despair had always been with him.
It was always there for him to embrace.
It was his friend. His other half. His mentality.
So how could he come here and then despair like he didn’t even know what it was.
No. This wasn’t it.
It wasn’t how it was going to work.
It wasn’t who he was.
He was the friend of despair.
The student of despair.
The son of despair.
The lover of despair.
He was Mikhail Hendrix, One Who Withstands Despair.
________________

chapters.title: Chapter 29: The Secret Behind Mikhail
chapters.content:
Chapter 29: The Secret Behind Mikhail
"Insane."
It was the old word that left Emily’s mouth as she saw the screen before her.
She couldn’t understand what just happened.
It all changed so fast.
Initially, if she had to be honest, she was kind of disappointed at the progress of Mikhail.
The score was increasing as steadily as ever but he had already started to show signs of struggle early on.
At 40, he was struggling quite much against the spirits.
Despite increasing the difficulty a little, the scale to measure his mental endurance was still the same.
So it made no sense to her what was happening.
At 52, Mikhail was almost going to collapse on the ground or dive out of the circle.
The sweaty and breathless expression on his face showed that he was almost done.
And yet, the score was nothing more than an average cadet.
Even with using all of her brains, Emily found it hard to find the problem in him.
His bodycheck before the test showed that there were no medical conditions that affected him.
So then why?
To prevent any further hardship for their future prospect, she was almost going to shut down the test when something unexpected happened.
The score that was increasing suddenly turned stagnant.
It stopped at 53.
At the same time, anger and self-hate came on Mikhail’s expression for the first time in Emily’s life.
The black-haired boy was an intriguing person to him, even outside the tests.
He barely showed any expression and when he did, it wasn’t much.
So this was the first time seeing such an intense emotion on his face.
She was startled when she saw him gritting his teeth and banging his fist on the ground.
Emily was convinced that this might be where he would finally give up.
Not just her but the whole lab.
But all their expectations were broken when his expression went back to as it was.
No. It wasn’t anything like before.
There were no signs of even a frown on his face. It was perfectly calm.
Rather, a deadly calm.
But the real shock hit them when suddenly, the mental endurance counter shot up at a breakneck speed.
53..
56..
60..
Emily stared wide-eyed at the monitor, not understanding what was going on.
64..
Her shocked eyes went to the monitor where Mikhail was seated.
And his expression...
It was calm as ever.
A collective intake of breath echoed in the room as all of them tried to grasp what was happening.
Mikhail’s heartbeat went back to normal. His blood pressure lowered back down.
Everything that showed signs of warning went back to their normal signs.
And yet, the mental endurance counter...
70..
And it broke his previous record.
Unable to let out a sound much less a word, Emily’s trembling eyes went to the monitor.
Where Mikhail was seated.
And his expression..
It was still calm.
But there was something else there now...
Drip. Drip. Drip.
Emily’s eyes widened and she rushed out of the lab room, towards the test room screaming,
"ABORT THE TEST, NOW!"
***
All of a sudden, the resistance he felt vanished.
The pain and struggle he felt vanished.
Mikhail felt at peace. True peace for the first time he came into the world.
It was as if he could feel nothing. No true emotion. Fear, pain, surprise, it was all gone.
No. It was wrong.
He could still feel them but...
Mikhail found them to have no effect on him.
They felt nothing more than a tickle or a mere fleeting feeling.
No matter what the spirits tried, his mind was at a perfect calm.
However, he felt the tickle turn into pinches soon enough.
It was getting more effective now.
Instead of continuing the trial though, everything suddenly disappeared before Mikhail.
Darkness returned and he felt his body warp back to what it was before, making him aware that the test had ended.
Slowly opening his eyes, he was assaulted by the bright light of the room.
Adjusting, he was surprised when he saw Emily in front of him, her eyes wide from shock.
’Hmm?’
He chose to quickly ask the question that was plaguing his mind.
"Why did you end the test?"
There was no frustration in his voice. And neither his face or eyes.
Not even anger or any other emotion, just plain curiosity.
At his words, Emily startled awake as if she was out of it before.
Mikhail saw her eyes avert from his gaze, confusing him on what happened.
"Y-yes, the test is cancelled." He heard her stutter.
"Why?" He asked back.
Mikhail saw her raise a finger and point towards his face, confusing him again.
’Huh?’
"Y-your face."
’What abou-’
It was then that realization hit him and he started to feel it.
The taste of iron, in his mouth.
Drip. Drip. Drip.
And the sound of something dripping became clear to his ears.
He quickly touched his mouth and the edges, feeling his bandages become wet.
Retracting his hand, he looked at it.
Crimson Red. Blood.
"Quickly head to the infirmary and treat this. How did you not notice?" Emily ordered him, turning to leave.
She was still not looking at him.
It was true, how did he not feel the blood while talking?
Quickly standing up, Mikhail started to head towards the door, leaving for the infirmary.
He didn’t bother to ask Emily why she was avoiding him. He was still out of it.
***
As Mikhail left the room, Emily was finally able to heave a sigh of relief.
Not just one, but multiple gasps.
It was as if her throat had just been released from a chokehold, making her able to finally breathe.
"W-What the hell was that?" Her shocked voice still stuttered.
The moment she entered the room, Emily was surrounded by a thick energy of bloodlust.
She was a Herald, and despite all that, it was as if death was lurking right by her side.
It was thick and heavy, making her heart heavy.
Despite not being the fighter type, she was able to handle energies like bloodlust quite well.
They were normal reactions from her target subjects.
But this one, no. It was as if it was the same but at the same time completely different.
If others said, I want to kill you, this one said, I’m going to kill you.
And the origin of this bloodlust?
The 20-year old black-haired boy sitting in the middle of the room, his expression as calm as ever.
The moment he opened his eyes, and those blue-crimson tinted eyes stared into her, she felt the bloodlust increase multiple folds.
Emily felt if she stared into it for a minute, breathing would become an impossible task for her.
That’s how heavy it was. And yet, even with all this, she couldn’t understand the reasoning behind it.
What did a 20-year old boy have to do to have this much bloodlust?
This wasn’t just a criminal-level intent. It was a pure demonic intent.
One that she should have immediately reported to the authorities upon seeing it.
But she didn’t. She didn’t want to lose Mikhail.
He was too valuable. Too perfect for her. He was a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity.
And this phenomenon only served to increase her curiosity.
Or maybe, if she had to be honest, it was something else.
A fear at the back of her mind that reporting wouldn’t do good to her.
Those crimson-tinted eyes dared her to try and report and unfortunately, she didn’t have the courage to do so.
’I can’t lose him, he’s way too important for me.’
Emily licked her lips.
The boy had just turned all the more interesting for her. All the more close.
But what still left her shocked was his final score.
She turned to stare at the hidden monitors in the walls, speaking to them.
"What was the boy’s final score?"
***
"Oh, I forgot to ask for my final score." Mikhail realized as he sat on the infirmary bed.
’Whatever, I’ll just ask later.’
***
"8-84 Ma’am." The reporter struggled.
That was the mental endurance of an expert Monarch and yet, a 20-year old undertrained cadet had just achieved this record.
______________

chapters.title: Chapter 30: Julian Perez
chapters.content:
Chapter 30: Julian Perez
Sitting in the infirmary, Mikhail drank a glass of water.
He was about to be discharged after being stuck in bed for an hour.
The nurse informed him that he had overloaded his cerebral mana veins.
It was fortunate that Emily had stopped the test or it could be much worse.
"You are fine now so you can go. Though, I heard it was your first test. Stop pushing yourself too hard or you’ll end up a cripple." The doctor lectured him.
Mikhail nodded, paying half-hearted attention to his words.
"I’ll try." He shook the hand of the doctor, before turning to leave.
"With the condition you are in, you will kill yourself in the near future."
"Okay."
Mikhail walked out of the infirmary.
Towards his next test.
***
Mikhail entered the elemental grounds, finding them already crowded.
In the distance, he could see the signs of different elements to guide the incoming participants.
Looking around, he could still find some signs of the previous battles.
Broken trees and claw marks on the ground.
It was definitely a fierce battle here and it made sense.
Elemental grounds were different from physical or drill grounds.
They had a higher density of mana particles in the surroundings through artificial sources.
It was still weaker than a place with natural density but it worked.
The academy used spirit magic and other artifacts to perform this phenomenon.
Staring ahead, Mikhail saw the elemental tests already underway.
And the one that caught his eye instantly...
Was the brown-haired easily outperforming everyone in the Cindralis section.
The way his crimson eyes instantly reacted to the miniscule movement of the figures.
And how his hands instantly weaved the spell to act, it was masterful.
The eye-body coordination was almost perfect.
To the point that the people near him didn’t even bother to try, already accepting their outcome.
That boy was Oscar.
’He’s as good as ever.’
A light smile came on Mikhail’s lips, feeling a sense of pride in him.
Early on in his childhood, he was the first one to notice how much of a talent Oscar had in Elemental Magic.
Possessing Cindralis himself, he was the first person to teach him on the uses of the element.
It was funny how quickly he surpassed him in this aspect. Terrifying.
But Mikhail didn’t feel the slightest jealousy over it. Oscar was family to him.
The more he advanced, he would only be happy for him.
As if hearing his thoughts, he was startled when Oscar’s eyes suddenly snapped toward him in the distance.
His crimson eyes locked with his sapphire ones and a wide cheerful smile spread on his tired face.
He waved his hand in full force at him in the distance, ignoring his test.
Reciprocating the gesture, Mikhail gave him a light smile and waved his hand before giving a thumbs up.
It expressed his satisfaction over his performance.
And that was all that Oscar needed.
Mikhail immediately saw his spirits rise up by a mile as he turned back to blitz through the test.
Besides him, he could see some boys staring admiringly with their mouths open at him.
And some staring at him with jealousy and rage.
Mikhail didn’t care though.
He was certainly protective of the boy, more than one would think.
His family was one of the things that could make him truly flip a switch.
But he never had to interfere, the men by themselves were enough to handle them.
Leaving Oscar to complete his test, he turned to his respective element.
Norvalis.
He saw the respective emblem of the element hanging in the distance, with the tests already underway.
Unlike Cindralis, there weren’t many people in Norvalis.
It wasn’t even Norvalis.
It was well known that the chance of awakening a Non-Materialistic element was much rarer than a Materialistic element.
In terms of power and strength, Non-Materialistic elements definitely lacked against the vice versa early on.
They were harder to control and lacked versatility in spells early on.
However both of them would be fixed with due time where the Materialistic elements would turn weaker.
Of course, if you never had much of a talent in any Non-Materialistic elements then you were done for.
Stepping forward, Mikhail walked over to the Norvalis section where he saw a gruff instructor overseeing the tests.
He seemed to be in his mid-30s, with a rough beard and wide stature.
His facial features displayed a rough persona, with a scar on his cheek and grey hair.
There were dark eye bags under his eyes, a well known side effect of overuse of Non-mat elements.
They placed too much stress on the caster, a reason why Mikhail opted to use it less even with all his talent.
"67, Next." The instructor’s deep voice came over the students.
Elemental Tests were graded in the same way as Mental Examinations.
From 1 to 100.
There were a total of 10 exercises where in each exercise, 5 points were given for completion and 5 for the time in which you completed it.
The cadet who just went by had scored a total of 67 marks.
Mikhail was about to raise his hand when someone intervened.
"I’ll go ahead."
He heard a familiar voice from beside him, graceful and polite.
Turning, he saw him.
It didn’t take him more than a moment to recognize him, just like every other cadet in the area.
Julian Perez, the commander for the 14th Squadron.
One of the famous men around the camp.
The Norvalis Prodigy, known for his exceptional control and power over the element.
There was no one in the camp that could match his skill level, or so it was said.
As their eyes met, an expression of shock came over Julian before he quickly masked it with politeness.
"Oh, Mika, I didn’t notice you were here. Please go ahead by all means."
He gestured forward.
Yes, Mika.
Mikhail already had quite a history with him.
And it was safe to say that it wasn’t good by any means. But it wasn’t bad either.
Almost like a rival friend/enemy relationship.
"No, it’s fine. You raised your hand first, I’ll wait. You can go ahead," Mikhail said without changing expression.
His words caused a playful smile to spread on his lips as he leaned closer, his eyes peering into him.
"Come on, you don’t have to act like we’re strangers."
Mikhail showed no reaction, almost making Julian click her tongue.
But he seemed to resist and lean even further into his ears.
"I’ll deal with you later, show-off." His tone completely changed.
Taking a step back, he turned.
"Now then, who am I to refuse if a gentleman like you allows me to go first."
Ignoring the glares at him from his followers, Mikhail focused on him as he stepped forward.
It had been 2 years since they last competed against each other.
He would be lying if he said he didn’t want to see how far he had come from that day.
_________________

chapters.title: Chapter 31: Their Past
chapters.content:
Chapter 31: Their Past
Three wispy black claws tore through the wooden moving structures with dot-accurate precision.
"That’s it." Mikhail heard the instructor announce.
At the same instant, the claws vanished and the responsible figure for them in front of Mikhail, relaxed.
He’d underestimated the black-haired boy.
Julian, in fact, had gotten much more powerful from the last time they completed.
And that was shown through his scores.
"79, next."
From a score of 62 2 years back to 79 now. A shocking improvement.
One that definitely wouldn’t be possible without hard work or artifacts and other illegal methods.
But since the latter ones weren’t available, there was only one plausible method.
And Mikhail could see the answer from his proud and happy expression as he turned to walk up to him.
"Did you see that!?" Hee asked, unable to hide his excitement.
Mikhail nodded.
"I did. Congratulations."
Julian smiled happily, a rare contrast to his usual attitude that he showed everyone.
"I know right-"
Not to let his true persona slip out, Mikhail was quick to help him by putting a hand on his shoulder.
"We are in public."
The few words were enough to startle Julian out of his self-joyment.
Looking around, he realized where he was and a bright red came over his face..
"I-"
Mikhail resisted a sigh.
’Whatever.’
To divert the attention from him, Mikhail quickly raised his hand.
"I’ll go next."
The instructor in the distance, looked over at him, his eyes trying to assess him.
A second later, the man nodded.
The words from Mikhail were not only enough to shift the attention towards him, but it also helped Julian compose himself.
Curiosity overtook his embarrassment as his eyes turned to Mikhail, who was now walking up ahead.
It was the only reason he even chose to be even here after the test.
To see how far Mikhail had progressed as well.
***
Mikhail Hendrix.
That was his name.
It was a name that had always intrigued Julian.
A mysterious cadet, rumored to have the same rank as him in Norvalis.
The element in which he was hailed as a prodigy.
Just the idea of someone even being able to rival him in his strongest field disgusted the young prideful Julian at the time.
For him, he was the best.
There could be no competition. There could be no person who’d even dare to take the throne from him.
But deep inside, even he was intrigued to see the boy who was rumored to be as strong as him.
When he saw him for the first time in person, he found him to be even more interesting than he expected.
Not just the powers but as a normal guy as well.
The young boy of 18 rarely showed expression on his face, even with his taunts or challenges.
Unlike him, he seemed to have no intention to challenge him back or beat him.
He didn’t even seem to enjoy showing off his power, opting to just be with his squadron.
Julian found him unique.
His behavior was unlike other boys of his age, having no interest in games or fun.
Rather, he seemed to always be practicing or training.
Unfortunately for the black-haired boy, even with all his tries to avoid a match, they eventually ended up in a match-up.
When they met that day on the ground, Julian could still vividly remember the scene of the battle.
He was crushed, his pride destroyed.
Brutally.
Utterly.
He’d heavily underestimated the boy. The difference between their final scores was shocking.
62 to 69.
A whole difference of 7 points between two people in which he was said to be the stronger one.
A whole difference of 7 points. Julian still knew the whirlwind of emotions he felt back then.
He felt embarrassment, shame and frustration over his loss.
Additionally, knowing that the boy would now rub his loss over his face worsened it.
But once again, the boy proved him wrong by giving the match no thought.
In fact, he gave his hand to him on the ground, pulling him up and commending him with a "Good job."
There was no emotion on his face while saying so but for some reason Julian knew he genuinely meant it.
The praise hit him differently, a reaction one would not give someone on their loss.
It was there that he realized how different Mikhail was from others. The boy was special in the sense of both power and mentality.
Which was why, in a move of surprise, he asked Mikhail to be his teacher rather than his rival.
He wanted him to teach him, despite being the same age.
Julian had learned to set differences and pride aside for improvement.
Even going as far as to request a squadron transfer.
Unfortunately for him, he was denied in both his requests by Mikhail himself.
The boy refused to teach him, telling that he had to improve and figure out his element himself.
It was his part, not Mikhail’s.
He was also disgusted at the fact that he would leave his whole squadron just to join him.
Julian could remember that it was the first time he saw an emotion on his face.
The refusal hit him a little badly. He did not expect it to go this way.
But he was able to take it better when Mikhail offered him a few pieces of advice.
However, the biggest problem for him started after that.
From the point of their friendship where he called him his nickname casually, it suddenly went to a point where Mikhail cut off all contact.
He refused to meet him or even look him in the eye when they were close.
When he called him, he didn’t respond as if he wasn’t able to listen to him.
He had completely cut him off, as if they were two unknown strangers to each other.
The stranger treatment hit him hard, breaking his spirit. He didn’t know what he had done to him for this.
His squadmates gave him no reaction as well.
It was a difficult time for Julian. One in which he then turned to hate Mikhail.
The anger within him caused him to despise him for what he did to him.
And there was only a single way to fuel his anger, by getting stronger and demolishing him the next time they were to battle.
Fast forward 2 years, Julian turned into not just the self-proclaimed strongest Norvalis Magus among the men but also one of the strongest men available.
In the Massacre Of the Gates, he had been given the charge of a whole group after arriving from another castle.
It was where he noticed Mikhail for the first time again after 2 years.
Julian wasn’t even sure if he hated him at this point. At one point in his quest to become stronger, he had forgotten about him.
His true purpose was to get stronger.
But after seeing his performance in the incident, it sparked that fire in him to battle him again.
Which was why the moment he saw him in today’s elemental tests, he knew it was the perfect chance for him.
To truly show him how much he had improved. To thoroughly crush him in the test, making him realize his mistake 2 years ago.
With a score of 77, Julian was very satisfied that he wasn’t going to be beaten.
He didn’t see him using Norvalis Essentia much so hhe knew that he had been slacking off on it for these 2 years.
It would be close.
But he would inevitably win.
Staring ahead at his back that got ready to fight, Julian knew it was finally time.
Time for him to get his win over him.
_______________

chapters.title: Chapter 32: Mikhail’s Turn
chapters.content:
Chapter 32: Mikhail’s Turn
Mikhail stood ready at the starting point for the test.
Turning to the instructor, he looked him in the eyes, nodding to indicate he was done.
The instructor nodded.
"We will begin now."
He gestured forward to the empty space in front of Mikhail.
"The first test is simple. I’ll tell you some shapes and the faster you mold your spell to that, the more points you get."
Mikhail nodded, already knowing the process.
"Okay. In 3, 2, 1.."
The black-haired boy focused on his front.
"Begin. Solid Circle."
Mikhail wasted no time, raising up his spell diagram.
There was no pre-spell for simple spell shapes so one had to form them by themselves.
"Norvalis." He spoke.
The use of Dragma for this challenge wasn’t allowed so he couldn’t use signs.
Not like he would reveal his card for a petty challenge anyways.
As he spoke, the first node on the spell circuit lit up like a black wispy marble.
The young man quickly moved to the next node.
"Solivex."
The second category that came after elements in a spell structure.
Its state.
And as said by the instructor, Mikhail chose Solivex, the runic name for Solid.
The second node lit up instantly and the spell segment that connected the first node with it also shone in a black glow.
Mikhail heard a multitude of gasps escape from behind at how seamlessly he transitioned.
He even felt the instructor looking at him impressively.
When forming a spell, there were several other factors that came into play.
These factors played a minor but important role in how the spell would turn out.
As an example, the first was mana input.
Overloading or underloading a node with mana could cause the whole harmony between the spell to break.
The mana resonance frequency between all the nodes had to be the same so the structure would hold up.
Any minor mistake and the spell could go into a failure and blast in the caster’s face.
It was one of the reasons why maguses often opted for pre-spells.
Spells took time and focus to be casted and a moment of distraction could cause their whole node structure to break.
A perfect input of mana into the nodes and a stable resonance frequency would allow seamless and faster connection of the nodes.
Just like how Mikhail did, adjusting his mana input to the perfect frequency for the spell.
It was the same tactic he used in the fight against Silent Pact.
As a Warden, Mikhail only had access to a 3-nodular spell framework.
As you advanced through the ranks, the number of nodes you could add would increase, allowing you to adjust further aspects of the spell.
Resulting in more complex and powerful spells.
It was both risky and advantageous.
A lot of tweaking could again, cause a spell-malfunction as well.
Being a certain rank didn’t mean he was restricted to only 3 nodes.
He could definitely add more. However, 8 times out of 10, he would be unable to tune the spell.
And even if he could cast it, he would definitely lose control of it.
So he wasn’t going to take the chances.
Turning back his attention to the spell, he moved to the third node.
Taking care to take care of all the factors, he completed the spell with the third node.
"Circora."
Runic name for Circle.
"Norvalic Circorium."
And sure enough, the moment he said it, the third node lit up and connected with all the nodes.
As the spell was completed, the diagram disappeared and a solid black circle formed in front of him.
No more than 4 seconds.
A collective gasp was let out in the air from behind him and even the instructor was surprised at his speed for a second.
Composing himself, he nodded with satisfaction and moved forward.
"Fluid Square."
"Norvalic Squalius."
"Gas Triangle."
"Norvalic Gossius."
And there on, it continued back and forth.
Mikhail performed the said task in literal seconds, not even taking time to understand or tweak the spell structure.
It was muscle memory for him. All the variable values in the nodular structure.
After a minute long back and forth, the instructor finally realized he had to move on.
He had gotten too immersed in the test with Mikhail.
Everyone could see how intrigued and impressed he was with the black-haired boy.
Coughing, the old man quickly moved on to the next test.
The second test was an extension of the first one.
He had to form a spell and move it to any desired spot the instructor told him to.
It was to show he had control over his spells.
There was no problem for Mikhail though. This was all child’s play to him.
"It should land here." The man pointed to a spot.
Nodding, Mikhail immediately formed a large black circle, sending it flying to the desired spot.
A second later, it crashed perfectly on the target.
Even for the aim, speed and precision of the spell, the caster had to tweak the aspects of the spell so they wouldn’t override each other.
Spell Physics was a major subject taught in everyone’s courses.
Mikhail had it on his fingertips. There was no need to think about it in his mind.
When forming a spell, his mind automatically adjusted all the values accordingly in his mind.
It was like a machine, showing how used he was to it after years of experience.
The tests continued like water, Mikhail breezing through them one after another.
He wasn’t perfect as his completion was still delayed in some tasks.
But it was still the best the instructor had seen till far.
After 5 tests of control, precision, aim, durability, the instructor moved to attack tests.
Multiple earthen structures were raised in front of him by the support staff.
With the instruction to break them, Mikhail quickly made short work of them.
He didn’t have the [Monarch] rank in Norvalis for nothing.
As the tests continued, the instructor posed several restrictions on him for the tests.
He had to adopt various paths and sometimes even destroy them all in a specific order.
It required a little more focus and input from Mikhail but overall, it didn’t pose much of a problem for him.
At this point, the whole crowd behind him had turned silent, even tired of gasping.
They got used to Mikhail just demolishing the task in a minute or less.
It was the same for the instructor who uttered one exercise after another.
Finally, after a mind-boggling performance of 8 minutes, Mikhail was finally done.
BOOM! BOOM!
Where Julian previously used claws to destroy the structures, his bullets ruptured a clean hole in their heads.
"That’s it." The instructor said, indicating the end.
Mikhail relaxed, wiping the sweat from his face as he finally relaxed.
The fact that was gasping slightly after all that showed that he wasn’t all that strong.
But he was definitely a monster.
Mikhail turned to the instructor, waiting for him to announce his results.
Looking at the sheet in his hand, the instructor raised his brows.
"Impressive. You tore through them like a breeze."
Mikhail nodded, accepting the compliment.
"Thank you."
The instructor nodded, before finally moving to his score.
__________________

chapters.title: Chapter 33: Oscar’s Surprise
chapters.content:
Chapter 33: Oscar’s Surprise
Mikhail walked out of the Norvalis Area after hearing his score.
A mind-blowing number of 81, allowing him to top everyone else in the test.
’1 category confirmed. Spellcasting and One-On-One Spars left.’
Out of the three he had chosen, he had 2 left now.
In the other 2 where it was normal for him to top at 1st, he was quite sure that he had clutched Mental Examinations again.
Despite it going a little unusual, Mikhail had a hunch that it went better than usual.
Physical Tests wouldn’t be a problem. It was the category he was most sure about.
Currently, he was heading over to his Spellcasting Tests.
It would be his last test for the day and he would do the last 2 categories tomorrow.
Spellcasting Tests were simple.
They were basically the same as Elemental Tests, but they focused more on the backend rather than the frontend of the spell.
The backend of the spell was the part where you formed and adjusted the spell and how you would release it.
The backend was known to be a more important and complex study than the frontend.
If one could master the factors involved in the backend, the overall strength of the spell could even advance a rank.
These minor factors could largely contribute to the result of a battle.
Since Spellcasting Tests weren’t all that different from Elemental Tests, they were held in the same ground.
Both of them required the use of mana so that was another factor.
As he was walking through the grounds, he heard a familiar call from behind.
"Mika."
Followed by a tap on his shoulder to indicate their presence.
Turning over, he saw Oscar arrive right beside him, done with his tests.
There was a bright smile of pride on his face, already indicating his results.
Not like he expected anything less from him.
He was a beast in Cindralis Magic.
"Oh hey, finally done with your tests?" He fell into step alongside him, allowing him to join him.
The brown-haired boy gave him a cheerful nod, his attitude as fiery as his element.
"Yup, it was a total breeze."
Mikhail smiled lightly before complimenting him.
"Good job."
He saw his expression freeze from surprise but then morph into a satisfied smile a second later.
It was apparent that a compliment from Mikhail was all he needed.
As they walked together, it was Oscar who spoke now.
"What about you Mika? How did your tests go?"
It showed on his face that he had been dying to ask this question.
Oscar or Icarus weren’t good at hiding their thoughts or intentions.
The twin brothers, Yvan and Modric were much better in these aspects.
Mikhail could understand why he hesitated to ask about it.
His whole squadron knew that he never performed to his full power in the tests.
Mikhail never had any intention or interest in doing so which was why he never topped these tests.
Oscar wanted to ask about his score, but didn’t want it to come across as a rude gesture that he was flexing his position.
Mikhail didn’t really care about it if he had to be honest, but he understood where she was coming from.
He would tell them even if he didn’t perform well, because he never tried clearing on top in the first place.
However, this time, it was an entirely different case.
"I got a score of 81," he told him.
An inquisitive look came on Oscar’s face as he tried to think on what to say.
’He doesn’t understand how good 81 is in Non-Mat elements.’
As Mikhail said before, Non-Mat elements were hard to control and weak at first.
So as compared to Mat-elements, their high score ranges were usually less.
Which was why it was a problem for Oscar.
He lightly tapped him on the back of his head.
"It’s the top score in my element. I won."
The words caused Oscar to freeze for a moment, as if he was trying to make sure he heard right.
His shocked crimson eyes locked with his blue ones, the thought causing him to freeze in his place.
"Wait wait, you won? Like like, you got first place in your category?"
His expression seemed to wonder if he was standing before the wrong Mika.
However, the nod of confirmation from Mikhail sent a punch of air through Oscar.
A second later, his expression was replaced by an otherworldly happiness for him.
"That’s great Mika!"
Mikhail felt some weird stares from the people beside him and he tried to calm Oscar down.
Unfortunately, it would take him a good 20 minutes to do so.
The cheerful guy was just more happier for his scores than his own ones at this point.
***
A stressful 25 minutes later, the duo arrived at the Spellcasting grounds.
Oscar didn’t pick this category up but he still followed Mikhail to see him perform.
With his talent in Cindralis, one would think that Oscar could perform exceptionally good here as well.
But surprisingly, that wasn’t the case.
And the reason for it was the furthest thing from what one would expect.
It was because Oscar didn’t think about spell factors or their values.
His body or his mind just calculated and set them on instinct.
The surprising part was that his instinct was so terrifyingly good that the spell would never break.
It would remain in perfect harmony.
Of course not everyone could do it. His Dragma also played a significant role in this.
"You can spectate from here, I’ll go ahead now," Mikhail informed him.
Oscar nodded.
"Okay. I’ll be watching you from here. Good luck." He apped him on the back.
Giving him a thumbs up, the young squadron commander went on ahead.
He saw that the tests had started for this category already as well.
There were already some candidates giving their tests up ahead.
Even though the use of Dragmas wasn’t allowed, Mikhail could get past the restriction with an Oath.
However, he didn’t see the need to use both.
Instead, he planned to just breeze through the category with his natural ability.
"Alright."
’Let’s do this.’
_____________
A/N: I’ll be skipping the spellcasting tests because they are more or less the same as shown in the elemental tests.
I don’t want to dump too much information about the spells right now.

chapters.title: Chapter 34: Cadet’s Dilemma
chapters.content:
Chapter 34: Cadet’s Dilemma
Mikhail let out a tired sigh as he walked out of the Spellcasting arena,
He was trying to ignore the shocked stares behind his back.
It was something he was going to need to get used to when doing this quest.
Even Oscar, who knew him better than anyone, was standing in front of him speechless.
Turning around, he saw the top 3 scores of the test written on the wooden board.
The second highest score was by a cadet named Clark Larrabee.
And that score was 74.
But then, his eyes went to the top scorer.
Mikhail Hendrix with a mind-breaking score of 86.
Spellcasting was a difficult field, especially early on.
The physics and mechanics behind it were known to break even the toughest and most intellectual of minds.
It was the reason not many picked it up as well.
Just scoring 80 or above 75 would place you as a genius cadet in the field.
But scoring above 80 in the early ranks? Unheard of.
And that was what Mikhail ended up doing.
It wouldn’t have been much of a surprise if he was doing it continuously.
No, everyone could swear that he used to score between 65 to 70 before.
So how did this big leap occur?
That was what the Spellcasting teacher, Morgan Quagmire, tried to ask Mikhail.
Only to be rejected politely that he was tired for the day and he would answer him some other time.
It wasn’t even a lie.
3 tests continuously had placed a high mental toll on him, making his head hurt.
Walking up to Oscar, he saw that the brown-haired boy was now more worried about his condition than what he did.
"Are you okay Mika?"
Mikhail tried to force a proper look on his face.
"Yeah, I am. Just a little tired."
Oscar nodded.
"Then let’s go back home."
Mikhail nodded, letting Oscar lead the path.
But as he was being led, he saw an unnecessary amount of stares being directed his way.
Before he could say something, Oscar was quick to point out the reason.
"You have gained too much spotlight with these tests."
He turned back, his crimson eyes interlocking with him.
"You are in their eyes now Mika. They finally recognize you for what you are."
For a moment, Mikhail could have sworn he saw a hint of sadness and inquisitiveness in his eyes.
But the next moment, Oscar had already turned and started leading him again.
Now, staring at the silent stares directed at him while he walked under the orange sky, Mikhail finally understood.
What the quest’s purpose actually was with this.
***
[The Next Day]
Mikhail came out of his tent at the slightest sight of dawn.
After an early jump to bed last night, he was feeling perfectly refreshed.
He would usually wake up his squadmates whenever he’d wake up but this time he chose to not do so.
They had a tiring day yesterday so they deserved to rest.
Especially for today’s tests as well.
After hearing about their performances, Mikhail was well satisfied with them.
The only time they ever placed under were if they competed against strong squadron leaders.
Otherwise, they mostly dominated the charts.
Whether it was Track Race or Alchemy tests.
Geared up after a shower, Mikhail started to head towards the physical grounds.
Physical Tests were held early on in the day to get a good measurement of everyone.
Where the air was fresh and everyone was on an empty stomach.
Reporting at the physical grounds, Mikhail found quite many people already there.
Focusing on the main motive, he walked to a safe spot in the ground and started doing his warmups.
He could feel a multitude of stares cast his way.
Not just because people were familiar with his record in the Physical Tests but also because of yesterday.
From what he heard from Modric, the name Mikhail Hendrix was a famous topic in the academy now.
Mikhail couldn’t care less about how it affected him anyway.
As he stood there doing warmups, Mikhail saw a familiar face enter the ground after a long while.
Vlahovic.
Despite the signs of tiredness and aging on his face from the battle, his energy was as strong as ever.
To the point that a single step from him in the ground was enough to alert everyone.
Silence fell through the whole ground at his appearance after a long while.
Unlike the last time, even if someone wanted to this time, nobody dared to object or question him about the incident.
No one could.
That’s how much people were terrified of this man.
"It’s been a while." His raspy hoarse voice echoed in the ground.
People could see how weak he had gotten from the battle.
Yet, for some reason, they felt as if his will didn’t waver at all.
And the curving of his lips into a sinister smile was all that they needed for confirmation.
That smile on his lips. It was infamous among every Physical Test candidate.
They called it the Smile of Doom.
Because if Vlahovic, the head of Physical Training, was to smile like this,
Every cadet knew hell was about to come.
And that’s exactly what it was.
Most of the tests followed the same structure of 100 Marks, like with Elemental and Spellcasting Tests.
And unsurprisingly enough, it was the same for Physical Tests.
Only that the 10 Tests carried out in Physical Tests were to vary instructor by instructor.
They could give you anything as long as it was related to your physical fitness.
A reason why not many people liked to pick this test up.
Especially not with Vlahovic as the head instructor on it.
As if to illustrate the despair every cadet was feeling in their heart, he pointed to a spot in the distance.
Following his cane, Mikhail’s eyes landed on a large pile of rucksacks and weapons by some trees.
"You each will take a rucksack and carry two weapons on your back." Vlahovic ordered, sending a horrifying chill down the cadet’s spine.
But his next words were what sent the nail down their coffins.
"Carrying at least 140 kilos on your back, you will climb the mountain behind your back and come back," he smiled deviously.
No wonder he was so infamous for his smile.

chapters.title: Chapter 35: Mountain Race
chapters.content:
Chapter 35: Mountain Race
Mikhail gazed around him, observing the participants.
And he was disappointed, if he had to be honest.
It had not even been 10 minutes since they started the test.
And yet, he could already see multiple tired faces around him.
While it was true that they couldn’t be blamed for a sudden rise in the weight from 70 to 120 this time, it was still a disappointment.
They were men of the hold.
They had to be used to unexpected situations.
And 120 wasn’t even all that much, at least not for Mikhail.
Even with all the weight on his back and the sharp incline of the hill, he had yet to break a sweat.
He was feeling as perfect as ever.
Among the 150 to 200 men that were running right now, he wasn’t that far behind.
Almost between the 120 to 140 mark.
He had intentionally not chosen to break forth to the top right from the start.
This was his usual strategy every time to crack the competition.
By staying behind first, it saved both his stamina and gave him time to assess the traps ahead.
The ones at front acted like dummies to test most of the traps anyways.
Unfortunately, Dragma and offensive use of magic wasn’t allowed.
Mikhail didn’t even dare to find a loophole since he knew the overseer was Vlahovic this time.
That guy’s awareness was on another level.
Moreover, he didn’t feel the need for his Dragma as well.
Magic use was allowed for evasion of traps and pre-spells were enough for this.
Focusing upward, Mikhail now started to increase his pace.
He saw people staring at him with wide expressions at how calm he was even with all the weight.
Most of them didn’t bat an eye though, they were already used to Mikhail.
They already knew what kind of monster he was.
In fact, when discussions were carried out for the results of Physical tests, the positions to be debated were always counted from second.
There was never a discussion or debate for the first position.
Because the holder’s name was already set in stone on that position.
Bending his knees, he focused his power on his toes, stopping his motion for a second.
The next moment, he shot straight up the mountain, through the trees like a meteor.
Grabbing branch to branch from trunk to trunk, Mikhail advanced through the terrain as if it was his home.
The flexibility in his body left even the most acrobatic of men speechless.
It was just a result of all the training Mikhail had put into his body.
Step.
Suddenly, as Mikhail’s foot landed on a branch, the twig snapped under his weight.
Losing balance, Mikhail started to fall down where a large hole opened in the ground.
A multitude of spikes shot out, intending to impale through him like a knife through butter.
But Mikhail’s expression betrayed his situation.
It was completely calm.
Placing his hands in front of him, he wasted no time to cast a spell.
"Cindralic Bormis."
Within a second, a trail of fire shot out from his hands, towards the spikes.
Using the reactive force, Mikhail skilfully maneuvered himself in the air to dodge the spikes.
They passed harmlessly from where he was before, meanwhile Mikhail had already moved ahead.
Cancelling his spell, Mikhail now landed on the ground.
But the moment he did, he felt a rope close around his leg, pulling him into mid-air.
’The number of traps have increased.’
Mikhail noticed.
Spinning on his heel, he tried to quickly force break free from the trap.
But the moment he tried, he suddenly felt a suppressive force on his body.
Losing his balance at the sudden force, Mikhail almost fell on the ground if not for his quick thinking.
"Aqualic Bormis."
Blasting a stream of water on the ground, Mikhail propelled himself into the air again.
Barely dodging another volley of spikes that awaited him if he so touched the ground.
’That old man..’
Mikhail realized.
There were some traps intentionally laid out for him, to make it difficult and test him at the same time.
But he didn’t feel frustrated.
Rather, Mikhail felt excited for this challenge.
’Alright, bring it on.’
Currently, he jumped straight to at least among the top 50 men with that sudden leap in pace.
The faster he finished, the better it was for him.
It had been almost 12 minutes.
His record time for the whole Physical Tests was 42 minutes with a score of 78.
He didn’t know if he had to beat the time or the whole score.
Regardless, he would just do both of them.
’Time to pick up the pace.’
He gazed up at the mountain, seeing a couple of men ahead of him advancing steadily through the traps.
For the first time in these tests, he was feeling a little thrilled.
This was why he liked Physical Tests and what the old man often gave him to challenge.
Standing on the ground, Mikhail looked at the bandages on his arms and legs.
These bandages weren’t just for fashion or show.
They were training equipment given to him by Vlahovic.
Each of these bandages around his arm, added at least a 10kg weight on one side.
In total, he was carrying at least 50 KG extra weight more than everyone else.
But the most shocking part was that he had been doing this for months.
He had gotten so used to the weights that it didn’t even feel weird with the additional pressure.
Not just that, but the tight bandages also served to restrict his flexibility and momentum.
It was to restrict and make him challenge the attack head on more times than rather evading it.
But there were often times that Mikhail used to untie them to relieve himself of the weight.
And for some reason, this time just happened to be one of them.
THUD! THUD! THUD!
Mikhail loosened the bandages around his arms and legs and let them fall to the ground, producing a loud thud.
That’s how heavy they were, which also casted some strange stares from him on the side.
But Mikhail didn’t care about that.
Right now, the only thing he was focusing on was the top of the mountain.
Immediately, the effects were felt by him as he felt a new sense of freedom and flexibility to his body.
Doing some light stretches and cracking his bones, Mikhail bent his knees, placing his hands over the ground.
Stretching his legs as far as he could, he pushed himself at full speed in the next second.
And the result...
Was a blur crashing through the trees at a break-neck speed.
__________

chapters.title: Chapter 36: End Of Physical Tests
chapters.content:
Chapter 36: End Of Physical Tests
WHOOSH!
Mikhail sped through the trees, descending down from the mountain to the finish line.
The moment he landed back on the ground, he let go of his sprint.
Small huffs escaped from his mouth as slowed down to a stop, wiping the sweat from his forehead.
He was back, and he was first.
The moment he took off his weights was when it all became a breeze for him.
He passed through the cadets and returned to the first place in a flash.
And it only took him a total of 19 minutes.
Catching his breath, Mikhail looked over to Vlahovic, who was standing in the distance.
The old man had a surprised but impressed grin on his face, nodding to express his satisfaction.
Mikhail nodded back, acknowledging his praise.
He turned back to look at the mountain, seeing the remaining cadets now arriving down as well.
The first one to pass the finish line after him was someone he knew very well.
Cameron Brooke, Commander of the 18th Squadron.
He was famous for being one of the only few commanders that were a tanker.
It was also why his physical abilities excelled so much.
His gigantic muscular body already coupled with his Size-Increasing Dragma, made him one of the strongest people around.
Despite being a heavy-hitter/tanker.
He was one of the major position holders in the Physical Tests, often ending up at 2nd or 3rd.
Behind him was someone he knew as well, albeit barely.
With short brown hair, the boy’s muscular body was the clear evidence of his current result.
James Thorneheart.
He was the Vice-commander of 12th Squadron, known to be a heavy-hitter as well.
Unlike Cameron though, he preferred using knuckles and his body for fights.
Mikhail had only heard his name time and time around but never knew him well enough.
Unlike Cameron.
That guy was also present in his platoon during the incident.
For some reason, Mikhail could not remember what happened to him in his previous life later on.
Being quite close in their pursuit of the line, it was unfortunate for James that Cameron was the first to win.
They arrived just some minutes after Mikhail, their bodies covered in sweat.
Arriving after 30 minutes would result in an automatic disqualification.
Mikhail saw both of them glare at each other for a second, the rivalry clear between them.
But then, both of them turned to stare at him meaningfully.
There was no angriness or frustration in them though, Mikhail could only see acceptance.
At this point, they had gotten used to being beaten by Mikhail.
From behind, Mikhail heard more noises of cadets arriving, their bodies out of breath.
Ignoring them, he focused on Vlahovic.
The old man was known to give no breaks between tests, making them extremely difficult.
And he was right.
"Nobody will take off their weights. Get down on the ground for 500 push-ups. Right now," He said, showing absolute calmness.
Terror instantly took over the cadet’s face at the order.
But Vlahovic’s face expressed no sympathy, erasing any chances of raising their disapproval on the task.
THUD!
A sound echoed in the ground, making everyone’s faces turn.
It was Mikhail, who had already started doing the task without any hesitation.
It was useless to look at Vlahovic for changes, they were just wasting their time.
And Mikhail couldn’t waste any time. He had a record to set.
As their gazes landed on Mikhail, two more sounds were heard.
THUD! THUD!
They were Cameron and James, who immediately followed Mikhail with no intention to lack behind.
"We are just wasting our time, hurry up!" One man shouted, getting to the ground as well.
If their collective time got over 1 hour for the exercises, that would result in failure as well.
Furthermore, in this exercise, if they failed to do 3 push-ups correctly or took a space of more than 5 seconds between pushups, they were disqualified.
Failing one exercise would result in failure in the whole category.
This was how difficult Vlahovic’s Physical Tests were.
And why not many picked them up.
People like Oscar and Modric would brutally fail here.
***
[30 Minutes Later]
It was finally over.
After a brutal half hour of harsh exercises that ranged from just legs to the whole body, the Physical Tests finally came to an end.
Drip. Drip. Drip. Drip.
Mikhail wiped the sweat from his forehead, looking out at the other cadets.
He could see cadets with closed eyes, dead on the ground, unable to move even a muscle.
It was clear how tough the tests were.
Even Mikhail’s clothes were completely drenched in sweat, sticking to his body.
They highlighted his toned and athletic muscles underneath, often hidden by his oversized white shirt.
He felt several glances at him from all around but he chose to ignore them.
He was only focused on the thing, the results.
And it was now time for them to be announced.
Coming forward to the middle of the ground, Vlahovic tapped his supporting cane at the ground.
Everyone’s attention moved to the old man, who carried a list in his hand.
"Now, I’ll be announcing the marks of the top 3 positions."
There was no exciting reaction from the crowd, but it wasn’t surprising.
It was always like this.
The first 3 were always more or less the same, especially this time with the harder difficulty.
"First off, at the third position, with a clear time of 48 minutes and 04 seconds is, James Thorneheart. 71 Points."
There were some appreciative claps heard from the crowd while the short–haired girl just nodded.
Nodding back to express his acknowledgement, Vlahovic moved on.
"Then, at the second position, with a clear time of 47 minutes and 11 seconds is, Cameron Brooke. 74 Points."
Again, some claps were heard from the crowd while the giant guy nodded to show his satisfaction.
Nodding, Vlahovic moved to the final result.
At the same time, Mikhail felt every gaze directed at him.
Because this time, there was something curious about his performance.
Despite the test being harder, this time, Mikhail was one of the fastest to complete the tests.
The difference between him and Cameron was quite a lot, making them wonder if he had broken his own record.
Even Vlahovic gave him a meaningful stare.
"Good job, Mikhail. I saw the effort you put in these tests."
Mikhail nodded, accepting the rare compliment from Vlahovic.
It was known among everyone how much the old man favored the 21th Squadron Commander.
He moved onto the final result next.
"Now, as for the result. For the first position, as always, with a record-breaking clear time of 39 minutes is, Mikhail Hendrix. 81 Points."
____________

chapters.title: Chapter 37: Avalon’s Message
chapters.content:
Chapter 37: Avalon’s Message
***
Rolling up his bandages, Mikhail walked back to his castle dorm where everything was already getting lively.
On the way, he was subjected to many stares but he had gotten used to it by now.
He had come to terms with the fact that it was going to be like this ever since he had been topping every category he was in.
And he knew this was the purpose of the mission too.
His mind went back to the flashback he had seen on the first day with Modric and Icarus in the room.
He remembered how their faces suddenly changed to rotten headless sacks resting in the snow.
His whole squadron laid dead before him with their bodies strewn out.
His own broken body covered in blood, resting against the wall of the warehouse in the wild.
He remembered those flashes from his past. It was his last days before his death.
But then, there was someone else with him.
A woman.
She was there with him in his last days, in the same condition as him.
Her face and features were blurred and so were the words she spoke to him.
He could remember nothing about her at all.
And then the vision had ended.
He still needed to find who that woman was.
Maybe someone from beyond the hold?
After all, it was where he had died.
He couldn’t be sure.
There wasn’t much to see in the vision, whether she was nice towards him or bad.
She might have just been the cause of speeding up his death or even delaying it.
He didn’t know this either.
But he knew one thing for sure, it was that she was tied to his death.
And potentially even maybe this oath imposed on him after he woke up.
He needed to find more about it.
And fortunately, he had found one main source for this after the main quest.
Character Progression.
He was currently at 15%.
And he was sure that the vision he saw with the girl after completing the quest was due to this.
Not only that but after the quest something else had changed too.
—————〔Oath XXX〕————
•
Condition: En*#2e the pr@*@#*$n of #*@#*@(#
[Penalty]
•
Death
———————————————
The first three words were visible now, just a little at least.
After that it was still, random letters.
He still couldn’t make any sense of it, even the first words on what they were.
